# Protocol of flexible Null Model Analysis


This protocol is for null model analyze of the joint effects of multiple factors. Null model predictions of specified multiple factor combinations are based on the responses of single factors. 


## Library


```{r cars, message=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
library(ggridges)
library(ggepi)
library(dplyr)
library(dabestr)
library(openxlsx)
```

## Data information


```{r pressure, message=FALSE}
df=read.xlsx("Dataset_Jeane.xlsx")
```


## Loading functions


```{r function, message=FALSE}
NullModel = function(object, selected_factors=vector(), n_perm = 500){
  
  output = list()
  CT = object[["summary"]][["mean"]][[1]]
  input=object[["data"]]
  population_CT= input[input[,as.character(object[["x"]][[2]])] == object[["result"]][["control_group"]][1], object[["result"]][["variable"]][1]]
  size_CT=length(population_CT)
  
  for (type in c("additive","multiplicative", "dominative")) {
    bs = numeric(0)
    for (id in c(1:n_perm)) {
    each_effect = numeric(0)
    k_CT = mean(sample(population_CT, size_CT, replace = T))
      for (treatment in selected_factors) {
      population_TR = input[input[,as.character(object[["x"]][[2]])] == object[["result"]][["test_group"]][which(object[["result"]][["test_group"]]==treatment)], object[["result"]][["variable"]][1]]
      size_TR = length(population_TR)
      k_TR = mean(sample(population_TR,size_TR,replace = T))
      
      # ES estimate depending on the type of null hypothesis
      if(type == "additive")        each_effect = append(each_effect,(k_TR - k_CT))
      if(type == "multiplicative")  each_effect = append(each_effect, (k_TR-k_CT)/k_CT)
      if(type == "dominative")      each_effect = append(each_effect,(k_TR - k_CT))
      }
    
    if(type == "additive") {
      joint_effect = sum(each_effect)
      pre_response = joint_effect+CT
    }
    
    if(type=="multiplicative"){
      z = 1
      for(m in c(1:length(selected_factors))) {
      z = z * (1 + each_effect[m])
      joint_effect = (z - 1)*k_CT
      }
      pre_response =joint_effect+CT
    }
    
    if(type=="dominative")  {
      joint_effect = each_effect[which(max(abs(each_effect))==abs(each_effect))]
      pre_response =joint_effect+CT
    }
    
    bs = append(bs, pre_response)
    }
  output[[type]] = bs
  }
  return(output)
}

NullModel_summary = function(null_data, actual_data = vector()){
  output = list()
  
  if(length(actual_data)<=2){
    output[["actual"]] = c(mean(actual_data),mean(actual_data),mean(actual_data),1)
    for (type in c("additive","multiplicative", "dominative")) {  
    bs = rep(mean(actual_data),length(null_data[[type]])) - null_data[[type]]
    p = length(which(bs>0))/length(bs)
    p = min(p, 1-p)
    output[[type]] = c(quantile(null_data[[type]], .025), mean(null_data[[type]]), quantile(null_data[[type]], .975), p)
    }
  }
    
  if(length(actual_data)>=3){
    #re-sampling of actual data
    size_actul=length(actual_data)
    bs_actual = numeric(0)
    for (i in c(1:length(null_data[[1]]))) {
      k_actual = mean(sample(actual_data, size_actul, replace = T))
      bs_actual = append(bs_actual, k_actual)
    }
    
    output[["actual"]] = c(quantile(bs_actual, .025), mean(bs_actual), quantile(bs_actual, .975), 1)
    
    for (type in c("additive","multiplicative", "dominative")) { 
      bs = bs_actual - null_data[[type]]
      p = length(which(bs>0))/length(bs)
      p = min(p, 1-p)
      output[[type]] = c(quantile(null_data[[type]], .025), mean(null_data[[type]]), quantile(null_data[[type]], .975), p)
    }
  }
  
  output = t(data.frame(output))
  colnames(output) = c("X2.5%", "mean", "X97.5%", "p_value")
  output = data.frame(ES = c("actual", "additive","multiplicative","dominative"), output)
  row.names(output) = c()
  
  return(output)
}
```

## Main analyze

### Single factor effect size (dabestr package).


Using dabestr package to calculate effect size of single factors.


```{r dabestr, message=FALSE}
pH.plot<-df%>%
  dabest(Treatment, pH, 
         idx = c("Control","R_low","R_high","A_low","A_high","I_low","I_high","MP"),
         paired = FALSE)

pH.plot.meandiff<-mean_diff(pH.plot,reps = 1000)

p<-plot(pH.plot.meandiff)
p
```

### Null model prediction based on specified factor combination.


In `NullModel` function, input object is the output of `mean_diff` function of dabestr package.

factor combination need to be specified by `selected_factors = c()`. 

For example, `selected_factors = c("A_low","I_low","MP")` specifies the factor combination of A_low, I_low and MP.

Adjusting Permutation times:`n_per = `, default permutation time = 500.


```{r Null, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
Null_modle = NullModel(pH.plot.meandiff, selected_factors = c("A_low","I_low","MP"))
```

### Significant testing between each null model prediction and actual data.


Extract actual responses of "A, I, MP (low concentration)" factor combination treatments from data set.


```{r actual data, message=FALSE}
AIMP_LOW=df[df[,"Treatment"]=="AIMP_low","pH"]
#Or actual responses can be put in manualy 
AIMP_LOW=c(5.14, 5.24, 5.24, 5.14, 5.23, 5.22, 5.23, 5.26)
```


Significance test, p<0.05 indicates significant difference. (null model failed to predict the results)


```{r null test, message=FALSE}
Null_modle_summary = NullModel_summary(Null_modle, actual_data = AIMP_LOW)
```

## Ploting 

```{r P, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
p_null = ggplot()+
  coord_flip() +
  geom_estci(data=Null_modle_summary, aes(x = mean, y = ES, xmin=X2.5., xmax=X97.5., 
                                     xintercept=pH.plot.meandiff[["summary"]][["mean"]][1]), center.linecolour = "black",
             size=0.6, ci.linesize = 0.5, position=position_nudge(y = -0.15))
  
p_null 
```
